question: Time to take you meds, Connor.
answer: You take it.

question: Now you know you got to be good 'cause you up for review this afternoon...
answer: I'm not taking it. Now I don't want any trouble...

question: Ain't no trouble at all --
answer: You... son of a... AAARRGH!!

question: Easy money!
answer: Where'd you learn all this stuff?

question: From my mom. My real mom, I mean. Come on baby... Let's go!
answer: That her? So she's pretty cool, huh?

question: Actually, no, she's a complete psycho. That's why she's up at Pescedero. She tries to blow up a computer factory, but she got shot and arrested.
answer: No shit?

question: Are you the legal guardian of John Connor?
answer: That's right, officer. What's he done now?

question: Could I speak with him, please?
answer: Well, you could if he was here. Be he took off on his bike this morning. Could be anywhere. You gonna tell me what his is about?

question: Kyle..? You're dead.
answer: I know. This is a dream, Sarah.

question: Oh. Yeah. They... make me take this stuff... Hold me.
answer: I love you. I always will.

question: Oh, God... Kyle. I need you so much.
answer: Where's John, Sarah?

question: They took him from me.
answer: It's John who's the target now. You have to protect him. He's wide open.

question: I know!
answer: Don't quit, Sarah. Our son need you.

question: I know, but I'm not as strong as I'm supposed to be. I can't do it. I'm screwing up the mission.
answer: Remember the message... the future is not set. There is not fate but what we make for ourselves.

question: Kyle, don't go!
answer: There's not much time left in the world, Sarah.

question: I was afraid... and confused. I feel much better, now. Clearer.
answer: Yes. Your attitude have been very positive lately.

question: It has helped me a lot to have a goal, something to look forward to.
answer: And what it that?

question: You said I could be transferred to the minimum security wing and have visitors if I showed improvement in six months. Well, it's been six months, and I was looking forward to seeing my son.
answer: I see. Let's go back to what you were saying about these terminator machines. Now you think they don't exist?

question: They don't exist. I see that now.
answer: But you've told me on many occasions about how you crushed one in a hydraulic press.

question: If I had, there would have been some evidence. They would have found something at the factory.
answer: I see. So you don't believe anymore that the company covered it up?

question: So what do you think, Doctor? I've shown a lot of improvement, haven't I?
answer: You see, Sarah... here's the problem. I know how smart you are, and I think you're just telling me what I want to hear. I don't think you really believe who you've been telling me today.

question: You have to let me see my son. Please. It's very important. He's in danger. At least let me call him --
answer: I'm afraid not. Not for a while. I don't see any choice but to recommend to the review board that you stay here another six months.

question: YOU SON OF A BITCH!! Goddammit. Let me go!! Silberman! You don't know what you're doing! You fuck! You're dead! You hear me!!
answer: Model citizen.

question: Get down.
answer: Whoa... time out. Stop the bike! Now don't take this the wrong way, but you are a terminator, right?

question: Yes. Cyberdyne Systems, Model 101.
answer: No way! Holy shit... you're really real! I mean... whoah! You're, uh... like a machine underneath, right... but sort of alive outside?

question: I'm a cybernetic organism. Living tissue over a metal endoskeleton.
answer: This in intense. Get a grip, John. Okay, uh... you're not here to kill me... I figured that part out for myself. So what's the deal?

question: My mission is to protect you.
answer: Yeah? Who sent you?

question: You did. Thirty years from now you reprogrammed me to be your protector here, in this time.
answer: This is deep. So this other guy? He's a terminator too, right, like you?

question: Not like me. A T-1000. Advanced prototype. A mimetic polyalloy.
answer: What does that mean?

question: Liquid metal.
answer: Radical.

question: You are targeted for termination. The T-1000 will not stop until it complete its mission. Ever.
answer: Where we going?

question: We have to leave the city, immediately. And avoid the authorities.
answer: Can I stop by my house?

question: Negative. The T-1000 will definitely try to reacquire you there.
answer: You sure?

question: I would.
answer: Look, Todd and Janelle are dicks but I gotta warn them. Shit! You got a quarter?

question: Look, Todd and Janelle are dicks but I gotta warn them. Shit! You got a quarter?
answer: Hello?

question: Janelle? It's me.
answer: John? Where are you, honey? It's late. You should come home, dear. I'm making a casserole.

question: Your foster parents are dead. Let's go.
answer: I need a minute here, okay? You're telling me it can imitate anything it touches?

question: Anything it samples by physical contact.
answer: Like it could disguise itself as anything... a pack of cigarettes?

question: No. Only an object of equal size.
answer: Well, why doesn't become a bomb or something to get me?

question: It can't form complex machines. Guns and explosives have chemicals, moving parts. It doesn't work that way. But it can form solid metal shapes.
answer: We spent a lot of time in Nicaragua... places like that. For a while she was with this crazy ex-Green Beret guy, running guns. Then there were some other guys. She'd shack up with anybody she could learn from. So then she could teach me how to be this great military leader. Then she gets busted and it's like... sorry kid, your mom's a psycho. Didn't you know? It's like... everything I'd been brought up to believe was just made-up fantasy, right? I hated her for that. But everything she said was true. We gotta get her out of there.

question: Negative. The T-1000's highest probability for success now would be to copy Sarah Connor and wait for you to make contact with her.
answer: Oh, great. And what happens to her?

question: Typically, the subject being copied is terminated.
answer: TERMINATED!? Shit! Why didn't you tell me? We gotta right now!

question: Negative. She is not a mission priority.
answer: Yeah, well fuck you, she's a priority to me! Hey, goddammit! What's your problem? Help! HELP!! I'm being kidnapped! Get this psycho off of me! Let go of me!! Oww! Why'd you do that?

question: You told me to.
answer: You have to do what I say?!

question: That is one of my mission parameters.
answer: Prove it... stand on one foot. Cool! My own terminator. This is great! Take a hike, bozo. Dipshit? Did you say dipshit?! Grab this guy. Now who's the dipshit, you jock douchebag? Put the gun down! NOW!! Walk away. Jesus... you were gonna kill that guy!

question: Of course. I'm a terminator.
answer: Listen to me, very carefully, okay? You're not a terminator any more. Alright? You got that? You can't just go around killing people!

question: Why?
answer: Whattaya mean, why? 'Cause you can't!

question: Why?
answer: You just can't, okay? Trust me on this. Look, I'm gonna go get my mom. You wanna come along, that's fine with me.

question: Now remember, you're not gonna kill anyone, right?
answer: Right.

question: Swear.
answer: What?

question: Just say "I swear I won't kill anyone."
answer: I swear I will not kill anyone. He'll live.

question: Open it or he'll be dead before he hits the floor.
answer: It won't work, Sarah. You're no killer. I don't believe you'd do it.

question: You're already dead, Silberman. Everybody here dies. You know I believe that. So don't fuck with me!
answer: Open the goddamn door!

question: Step back! Down on the floor! Now!
answer: Get her! Go around, goddamnit! Go around!!

question: Cool.
answer: You okay?

question: I said I was okay.
answer: It was stupid of you to go there. Goddamnit, John, you have to be smarter than that. You're too important! You can't risk yourself, not even for me, do you understand? I can take care of myself. I was doing fine. Jesus, John. You almost got yourself killed.

question: I... had to get you out of the place... I'm sorry, I...
answer: Stop it! Right now! You can't cry, John. Other kids can afford to cry. You can't.

question: This T-1000... what happens when you shoot it?
answer: Ballistic penetration shocks it, but only for a few seconds.

question: Can it be destroyed?
answer: Unknown.

question: Pull in here. We have to ditch this car. You look like handmade shit.
answer: So do you. I have detailed files on human anatomy.

question: I'll bet. Makes you a more efficient killer, right?
answer: Correct.

question: Can you see the pin switch? No!!!!
answer: Out of the way, John!

question: No! Don't kill him!
answer: It, John. Not him. It.

question: Alright, it! We need it!
answer: We're better off by ourselves.

question: But it's the only proof we have to the future... about the war and all that.
answer: I don't trust it! These things are hard to kill, John, believe me, I know. We may never have this opportunity again.

question: Affirmative.
answer: No, no, no. You gotta listen to the way people talk. See, you don't say like "Affirmative" or some shit like that. You say... no problemo. It someone comes off to you with an attitude, you say "eat me"... if you wanna shine them on, it's "Hasta la vista, baby".

question: "Hasta la vista, baby"?
answer: Yeah, or "later, dickwad." Or if someone gets upset you say "chill out." Like that. Or you can do combinations.

question: Chill out, dickwad.
answer: That's great! See, you're getting it.

question: No sense of humor. And that's another thing. You could lighten up a bit, yourself. This severe routine is getting old. Smile once in a while.
answer: Smile?

question: Yeah. Smile. You know. People smile, right? Watch. Hi. Nice place you got here. How's business? Okay. Bad example. Over there, look. Like that. I don't know, maybe you could practice in front of a mirror or something. We're not gonna make it, are we? People, I mean.
answer: It is in your nature to destroy yourselves.

question: I need to know how Skynet get built. Who's responsible?
answer: The man most directly responsible is Miles Bennet Dyson, Director of Special Projects at Cyberdyne Systems Corporation.

question: Why him?
answer: In a few months he creates a revolutionary type of mircoprocessor.

question: Then what?
answer: In three years Cyberdyne will become the largest supplier of military computer systems. All stealth bombers are upgraded with Cyberdyne computers, becoming fully unmanned, Afterward, the fly with a perfect operational record.

question: Uh huh, great. Then those fat fucks in Washington figure, what the hell, let a computer run the whole show, right?
answer: Basically. The Skynet funding bill is passed. The system goes on-line August 4th, 1997. Human decisions are removed from strategic defense. Skynet begins to learn, at a geometric rate. It becomes self-aware at 2:14 a.m. eastern time, August 29. In a panic, they try to pull the plug.

question: And Skynet fights back.
answer: Yes. It launches its ICBMs against their targets in Russia.

question: Why attack Russia?
answer: Because Skynet knows the Russian counter-strike will remove its enemies here.

question: Jesus. How much do you know about Dyson?
answer: I have detailed files.

question: You going to work all day?
answer: I'm sorry, baby. This thing is just kicking my ass. I thought we had it with this one... ... but the output went to shit after three seconds. I'm thinking now it's the way I'm matrixing the command hierarchies...

question: You need a break. You'll see it clear when you come back.
answer: I can't

question: Miles, it's Sunday. You promised to take the kids to Raging Waters today.
answer: Oh. I can't, honey. I'm on a roll here. Baby, this thing is going to blow 'em all away. It's a neural-net process --

question: I know. You told me. It's a neural-net processor. It thinks and learns like we do. It's superconducting at room temperature. Other computer are pocket calculators by comparison. But why is that so goddamn important, Miles? I really need to know, 'cause I feel like I'm going crazy here, sometimes.
answer: I'm sorry, honey, it's just that I'm thiiis close. Imagine a jetline with a pilot that never makes a mistake, never gets tired, never shows up to work with a hangover. Meet the pilot.

question: Why did you marry me, Miles? Why did we have these two children? You don't need us. Your heart and your mind are in here. But it doesn't love you like we do.
answer: I'm sorry.

question: See, I grew up in places like this, so I just thought it was how people lived... riding around in helicopters. Learning how to blow shit up. Then, when Mom got busted I got put in a regular school. The other kids were, like, into Nintendo. Are you ever afraid?
answer: No.

question: Not even of dying?
answer: No.

question: You don't feel any emotion about it one way or the other?
answer: No. I have to stay functional until my mission is complete. Then it doesn't matter.

question: Yeah. I have to stay functional too. "I'm too important". It's definitely you. There was this one guy that was kinda cool. He taught me engines. Hold this a second. Mom screwed it up, of course. Sooner or later she'd always tell them about Judgment Day and me being this world leader and that's be all she wrote.
answer: Torque wrench please.

question: Here. I wish I coulda met my real dad.
answer: You will.

question: Yeah. I guess so. My mom says when I'm, like, 45, I think, I send him back through time to 1984. But right now he hasn't even been born yet. Man, is messes with your head. Where's that other bolt? Thanks. Mom and him were only together for one night, but she still loves him, I guess. I see her crying sometimes. She denies it totally, of course. Like she says she got something in her eye.
answer: Why do you cry?

question: You mean people? I don't know. We just cry. You know. When it hurts.
answer: Pain causes it?

question: Uh-unh, no, it's different... It's when there's nothing wrong with you but you hurt anyway. You get it?
answer: No.

question: Alriight!! My man!
answer: No problemo.

question: Mommm!! Wait!! "No fate." No fate but what we make. My father told her this... I mean I made him memorize it, up in the future, as a message to her -- Never mind. Okay, the whole thing goes "The future is not set. There is no fate but what we make for ourselves."
answer: She intends to change the future somehow.

question: I guess, yeah -- Oh shit!!
answer: Dyson.

question: Yeah, gotta be! Miles Dyson! She's gonna blow him away! Come on. Let's go. LET'S GO!!
answer: This is tactically dangerous.

question: Drive faster.
answer: The T-1000 has the same files that I do. It could anticipate this move and reacquire you at Dyson's house.

question: I don't care. We've gotta stop her.
answer: Killing Dyson might actually prevent the war.

question: Shut up! SHUT UP!! Motherfucker! It's all your fault! IT'S YOUR FAULT!!
answer: Mom? You okay?

question: I couldn't... oh, God. You... came here... to stop me?
answer: Uh huh. It's okay. It'll by okay. We'll figure it out.

question: I love you, John. I always have.
answer: I know, Mom. I know.

question: We need your truck.
answer: Faster! He's right on us!

question: Drive for a minute.
answer: Where you going?!

question: Hasta la vista, baby.
answer: Okay, Mom, we gotta get out now, come on. That's it.

question: We don't have much time.
answer: What? Come on! Let's go! Come on, Mom, you can do it! Come on!!

question: Keep going. RUN!
answer: Come on, you gotta try... please, Mom. Get up! Mom! MOMMM!!

question: SHOOT!!!!
answer: I need a vacation.

question: Is it dead?
answer: Terminated.

question: Will it melt in there?
answer: Yes. Throw it in. And the chip.

question: No. There is another chip. And it must be destroyed also.
answer: No!

question: I'm sorry, John.
answer: No, no no!! It'll be okay. Stay with us!

question: I have to go away, John.
answer: Don't do it. Please... don't go --

question: It must end here... or I am the future.
answer: I order you not to!
